“Why are you so keen about virtue?” Svidrigaïlov laughed.  
“I am a sinful man. Ha-ha-ha!”  

“You provided for Katerina Ivanovna’s children,” his friend said.  
“Though you had your own reasons.”  

“I love children,” Svidrigaïlov replied.  
“On my first day here, I rushed to the haunts.”  

He paused, recalling the town’s familiar stench.  
“Peasants drink vodka. Young people dream impossible dreams.”  

He shuddered at the memory of a dance hall.  
A thirteen-year-old girl danced, blushing and ashamed.  
Her mother sat against the wall, silent.  

Svidrigaïlov grimaced.  
“Such progress,” he muttered, watching the scene unfold.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Svidrigaïlov reflects on human nature, self-deception, and the moral decay he observes in society.
